quotes.quote: TheÂ prestigeÂ you acquire by being able to tell your friends that you know famous men proves only that you are yourself of small account.

ChronologicalÂ prestigeÂ is tenacious: once attained, it can't be shed; it increased moment by moment, day by day, pressing its honours on you until you are lavishly, overly endowed with them. Until you literally sink under them.
Often times, the more power and prestige a person achieves, the more arrogant a person can become.
HisÂ renownÂ has been purchased, not by deeds of violence and blood, but by the diligent dispensation of pleasure.
Prestige is the shadow of money and power.
All the money, all the prestige in the world will never make up for the loss of your freedom.Â
A man'sÂ renownÂ is like the hue of grass, Which comes and goes.
In a dying civilization, politicalÂ prestigeÂ is the reward not of the shrewdest diagnostician, but of the man with the best bedside manner.
TheÂ renownÂ of great men should always be measured by the means which they have used to acquire it.
There can be no prestige without mystery, for familiarity breeds contempt.
PrestigeÂ and premium will also play an important role in the future. But some people define these values differently today.
TheÂ renownÂ which riches or beauty confer is fleeting and frail mental excellence is a splendid and lasting possession.
Measuring nationalÂ prestigeÂ by gold medals is like using viagra to judge the potency of a man.
RenownÂ awaits the commander who first restores artillery to its prime importance on the battlefield.
Renown is something people have always wanted, but maybe what's modern is that it's considered a virtue, this desire, rather than a vice. I might be wrong about this.

To feminine eyes a man'sÂ prestige, or his fame, envelops him in a luminous haze which obscures his faults. The triumphs of an aviator, an actor, a football player, an orator are often responsible for the beginning of a love affair.
